.



Clinton St., mix of trucks, autos and parked cars





lssues and Problems

While there are important opportuni-
ties for future development in Canton,
there are also significant problems which
must be overcome if the area is to realize
its full development potential. Among
these are:

*Traffic Congestion - Completion of
Interstate-95 should reduce one of
the major problems that has plagued
Canton for years: truck traffic using
local streets in surrounding residential
communities.

However, several other transportation
problems may persist in the future,
most notably heavy traffic congestion
on many of industrial Canton’s streets.
This problem results from several
factors: the large number of people

“employed in the area, the emptying of
traffic into the area from the Harbor
Tunnel Thruway and from Interstate-
95, the queuing up of trucks waiting to
unload cargo at the area’s many piers,
and the large number of railroads that
cross congested streets.

The planned construction of new
streets and the widening and recon-
struction of existing streets are
designed to help reduce congestion
and to give motorists alternative
routes. However, the proposed expan-
sion of General Motors, the develop-
ment of Holabird Industrial Park,

the recently completed berth at the

t

Dundalk Marine Terminal, and the
development of the Canton Seagirt
Terminal are expected to bring addi-
tional traffic into the area further con-
tributing to the congestion problem.
To help accommodate this new traffic
several further street improvements
may be needed in the future.

*Rail Problems - The Canton area con-

tains an extensive rail network. Both
Conrail and the CSX Railroad maintain
yards in the area for direct delivery to
local industrial and port users. Trains
are switched between these two major
lines and moved to business loading
docks by the Canton Railroad. The
most important rail issue facing Canton
concerns the future of this small
switching railroad. The continued
operation of a switching railroad is
critical to a number of the area’s indus-
tries. It is anticipated that the recent
purchase of the Canton Railroad
assures the area of service in the
future.

Several other issues also face Canton’s
rail system. Traffic bottlenecks created
by at-grade rail crossings on Boston
Street, Newkirk Street (near Holabird
Avenue and near Newgate Street),
Ponca Street, Holabird Avenue, and
Newgate Street pose transportation
problems for the area. The at-grade-
crossing at Boston Street is especially
hampering. Six tracks cross Boston
Street at-grade and the B & O bridge,
which has an 11 foot clearance from
the roadway, adds to the difficulties.
Increased coal shipment for the
Consolidation Coal Terminal may
aggravate’this situation. Besides these
rail/auto conflicts, the rail system itself
suffers from several serious operational
problems.

*Environmental Problems - Canton also

faces several environmental problems.
The absence of public sewers in west
Canton means that industries must
provide their own treatment systems or
discharge into the harbor. While
environmentally necessary, installing a
package treatment system is costly. This
added capital expense can discourage
firms interested in locating or expand-
ing in the area. Given Canton’s close-
ness to the harbor and the area’s high
water table, there is also some ques-
tion as to whether existing septic
systems can offer adequate protection
against soil contamination. On the
other hand, extending sewer lines to
west Canton would be particularly
costly for the City because no federal
funding is available for providing sewer
lines to private industries.

Canton’s other environmental problem
is meeting federal air quality standards.



43

43
